text: Yeah, no, absolutely. And I'll even back up and tell you that I can guarantee a lot of people in the hedge fund community will take issue with that statement because I've lived it real time. But so I joined an asset manager called Lister Watson in January 1 of 2008, just as things were getting interesting. And they had a couple of different components to the business, which was appealing to me. They had a third-party marketing arm, which had been around raising money for hedge funds since the mid-90s. They had a fund-to-funds group, which had I think three different fund-to-funds, about $2 billion in assets. So they weren't huge by any stretch, but they were big enough, coupled with the fact that they had this kind of third-party marketing arm that was early in the game raising money for hedge funds. They had a lot of access to market managers. So I was hired. I was coming out of American Express, actually, where I was working in the quantitative risk underwriting department. So the guy that hired me was a quant. He wanted to... He had a lot of kind of... Skunkworks type projects in the mix, over and above kind of the traditional manager due diligence, attribution analysis. And so he wanted... He was looking for a certain skill set to bring on board and work under him. So he hired me, started, like I said, beginning in 2008, which was the perfect time. And the first thing he had was he was a big data guy. And I don't mean big data. And that term wasn't around back then. So big in the sense that he appreciated having his own database, of managers, scores. He actually developed his own kind of manager ranking score that ultimately ended up getting patented. And this was all in Access, like Access 2001 database. So the first job he had was like, just figure this out. So I moved it all to SQL, automated a bunch of stuff. We had kind of nice reporting sitting on top of it. Also, because of that, I was going to all the manager meetings, all the cap intro events. They had two full-time guys doing manager due diligence reports. But I went on a lot of the other stuff. And I was like, I'm going to do this. I'm going to do this. And I went on every single one of those meetings. So it was phenomenal because it was just a ton of data points at a very interesting time. Interestingly, having been at Amex actually in 2007, that was when the bear funds were blowing up. And I can say it now, but we were sitting there. American Express was unique because they owned their POS network, which meant they had a lot of data, proprietary data that the other credit card companies didn't have. And so we were seeing things like revolve rates skyrocket even among the prime customers. And so there was a lot of... By the time I came in, I was like, I'm going to do this. I'm going to do this. I'm going to do this. I'm going to do this. I'm going to do this. I'm going to do this. I'm going to do this. There was a lot of chatter, a lot of writing on the wall that things might be going south, like I said, particularly after the bear funds blew up in 2007. So obviously, 2008 happened. Well, let me back up. One of the things that immediately struck me even before Q4 2008 was I was expecting... This was my first job on Wall Street. And I was really anxious to pull back the curtain and understand like, all right, what's the secret? I'm in the club now, guys. Tell me where the alpha comes from. And it was just a lot of... The same story. Every strategy was different, but the long-street equity guys were all telling the same story. Bottoms up stock pickers. They spent two years at a bank covering this sector. They look at it a different way than everybody else, which is what everybody else says. The distress guys all had the same story. Stat arb, convert bond arb. It was difficult from that to segregate who really had a persistent alpha generating process. And even powwowing with the other analysts and sitting in the investment committee meetings, I was observing real-time the decision-making process. And it was just... There was a lot of homogeneity within the hedge fund strategies, or so it appeared to me. And so Q4 2008 happens, coming out of that. And not surprisingly, or perhaps surprisingly, hedge funds didn't really perform that well. Certainly long-street equity funds. They were... Depending on what index you look at, our funds were down between 20% and 30% for presumably when they should have been. And so that's a big part of the reason why we're seeing a lot of this. The other part of that too is coming out of 08, we started seeing all these gating provisions thrown up. Managers... It makes sense. I get it in illiquid credit and distressed asset classes. But if you're trading publicly traded equities, you may not like the bid that you're getting on those stocks, but they're liquid. You can sell them. I remember one manager, even in the credit space, said that. People are saying there's no bids for things out there. He's like, oh, there's bids. He's like, you may not like what the bid is, but somebody's on the other end picking up that phone. And so we were coming out of 2008, 2009, like a lot of other fund to funds, with this existential crisis between investors were really becoming sensitive to fees, starting to question the hedge fund value prop, the transparency, the liquidity. Again, this is public at this point, so I can say it, but we were... One of the fund to funds was invested in Harbinger. And I remember it was... We were sitting on the... Lister Watson was, I believe, one of the funds on the creditor committee that after Phil Falcone borrowed $100 million from the fund to pay his personal taxes, that was just one of the final straws where we were talking to a lot of other institutional investors. I remember as a cap intro talking to a guy from a very big pension fund, and he was just in complete disbelief that this... And he's like, yes, I understand it was in the docs. He didn't do anything illegal, but that just brought to the forefront what up until that point had been an academic idea of the credit card. And I remember that he was like, I'm not going to do that. And he was like, I'm not going to do that. And he was like, I'm not going to do that. And I remember the idea of the credit card being the call option for the hedge fund manager. The idea where if he loses money, he doesn't really have any skin in the game. He still clips his 2% management fee, but he's at certain points, they're incented to take perhaps asymmetric or uncompensated risks because it's a call option. And so anyway, first half of 2009, this is all rising to the top. A lot of fund to funds, like I said, are questioning their own value prop. There was even... I remember being at a conference talking about... And somebody's questioning the value proposition of funds. And I remember being at a conference talking about... And somebody's questioning the funds of fund to funds, the fund to funds cube type model. I just remember going back, we were talking about... It was almost a Dilbert strip. We were sitting there around the investment committee back at the office. At some point, this is just getting ridiculous. People are going to say enough is enough. And so meanwhile, we had the guy that hired me, Mark Frieden, and I had already been doing a lot of work on the attribution side, real understanding, is this hedge fund, aside from what their process is, what the qualitative write-up says, are they adding value relative to their peer group? If so, how much? How do they do it? And one of the things that followed on from that was this idea of not just running factor attribution against ethereal factors, but really starting to put constraints on what those factors were, and specifically look at things that we could trade. Bass and Mandra had a broker-dealer. And so this was something we started really considering, was the idea of, all right, if there's a lot of beta... And that was one of the things, so let me circle back to the very beginning when I was talking about a lot of the stories seem the same. Well, fast forward, by the end of 2009, early 2010, we did a real deep dive. My full-time job at that point became really trying to dig into the idea of statistically replicating some of these risk return streams. And what we found was that there's just a lot of systematic risk in these different hedge fund strategies. So hedge funds as an asset class, maybe not so much for obvious reasons. But we found that there's a lot of risk in these different hedge funds. And so we started looking at how we could do this. And we found that there's a lot of risk in reasons. Long-term equity funds are employing very different strategies, harvesting very different risk premium and credit funds or stat arb or things like that. But if you segment the strategies well, and I'll come back to that because that wasn't necessarily a trivial process, but we had our own database. If you really create these homogenous groups of hedge fund strategies, you find that there's a lot of the same underlying risks driving all the funds in that strategy. And this was about the time that, like I said, the idea of hedge fund replication was really coming to the fore out of academia into products on Wall Street.
